abstract: Present remarks by the editor as he comes to the end of a six year tenure as editor and two and half years as associate editor. He takes the opportunity to discuss the organizational context of the journal, offer some opinions about the manuscript review process, and offer some general impressions about the current state of the substantive literature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
title: Editorial: Some Remarks From the Outgoing Editor

abstract: The number one problem with abstracts is too much approach, not enough arrival. Sometimes abstracts are so generically written that they do not pique the reviewers’ interest at all. Many read like this: “Topic A is increasingly important in the global marketplace. Drawing upon the literatures in B, C, D, and E, we present a general framework for understanding A. Data were collected from a wide variety of ﬁrms and several interesting patterns of ﬁndings emerged. The article concludes with a discussion of future research directions and implications for management practice.” Abstracts are your ﬁrst chance to make a positive impression on reviewers; try to give the readers some concrete information to get them excited about your work.
title: The Devil is in the Details: Converting Good Research into Publishable Articles
title-short: The Devil is in the Details

title: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to Publication: Newcomers' Perspectives on Publishing in the Organizational Sciences

publisher: Sage PublicationsSage CA: Thousand Oaks, CA
title: Some Candid Thoughts on the Publication Process:
title-short: Some Candid Thoughts on the Publication Process

title: Some Propositions About Getting Research Published
Anatomy of an R&R (Or, Reviewers are an Author's Best Friends…)
